summary: This is a Palm Beach Police Department incident report documenting interviews conducted on November 21, 2005, with former Epstein employees Juan and Maria Alessi. The interviews, conducted in the presence of a prosecutor and their attorney, detail their observations of young masseuses visiting Epstein's Palm Beach home and the aftermath of massage sessions, including cleaning sex toys. The report also notes contact from a private investigator working for Epstein's defense attorney prior to the police interview.

persons.name: Juan Alessi
persons.context: Former employee of Jeffrey Epstein for 11 years, interviewed by police on November 21, 2005. Described his duties, setting up massage tables, and cleaning sex toys after massages. Observed that masseuses became younger towards the end of his employment.

persons.name: Maria Alessi
persons.context: Former employee of Jeffrey Epstein for 8 years (1994-2002), interviewed by police on November 21, 2005. Stated her work involved cleaning and preparing the house, and she observed young masseuses visiting but did not know them personally.

persons.name: Donnie Murrell
persons.role: Attorney for Juan and Maria Alessi
persons.context: Attorney present during the police interviews of Juan and Maria Alessi on November 21, 2005.

persons.name: Daliah Weiss
persons.context: Prosecutor who arranged for the subpoena and interview of the Alessis. Met with the Alessis and police on November 21, 2005, and requested a court reporter.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The individual who employed the Alessis. The report details the Alessi's observations of massage sessions with young girls and related activities at his Palm Beach home.

persons.name: Ms. Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned by Juan Alessi as Epstein's girlfriend whom he initially dealt with before dealing directly with Epstein.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Attorney whose law office employed a private investigator who contacted Juan Alessi prior to his police interview to ascertain what he would tell police.

connections.description: Juan Alessi was employed by Jeffrey Epstein for 11 years as a house manager, driver, and maintenance person.
Maria Alessi was employed by Jeffrey Epstein for 8 years as a house cleaner and preparer.
Donnie Murrell was the attorney present representing Juan Alessi during his police interview.
Donnie Murrell was the attorney present representing Maria Alessi during her police interview.
Juan Alessi stated he initially dealt with Ms. Maxwell, Epstein's girlfriend, before dealing directly with Epstein.
Roy Black is identified as a defense attorney, and his investigator contacted a witness (Juan Alessi) in the Epstein case, implying a defense relationship.
ASA Daliah Weiss subpoenaed and interviewed Juan Alessi as part of the investigation into Epstein.

events.title: Police Interview of Juan and Maria Alessi
events.description: Juan and Maria Alessi, former employees of Jeffrey Epstein, are interviewed by police at the State Attorney's Office in the presence of ASA Daliah Weiss and their attorney, Donnie Murrell. A court reporter records their statements.

events.title: Private Investigator Contacts Juan Alessi
events.description: A private investigator from the Law Office of Roy Black contacts Juan Alessi to meet and ascertain what he was going to tell the police about Epstein.

events.title: Maria Alessi's Employment Period
events.description: Maria Alessi states she worked for Jeffrey Epstein from 1994 through 2002.

keyFacts: Juan Alessi, Epstein's former house manager, stated that towards the end of his employment, the masseuses visiting Epstein's home appeared to be 'sixteen or seventeen years of age at the most.'
Juan Alessi described having to wash a 'massager/vibrator and a long rubber penis' found in the sink after massage sessions, and that the bed 'would almost always have to be made after the massage.'

Maria Alessi confirmed that two or three different, young-looking masseuses would come to the house per day when Epstein was in residence, and that the Alessis were instructed to avoid encountering Epstein during his stays.
Prior to his police interview, Juan Alessi was contacted by a private investigator from defense attorney Roy Black's office, who met with him at a restaurant to discuss what he would tell police.
The interviews were conducted under subpoena with a court reporter present, and the information was subject to a protective order, indicating the sensitive nature of the investigation.
